subject: RE: [junit] names for overloading methods
msgSnippet: Uwe, We have done it both ways and seen that it is 6 one way, 1/2 a dozen the other.  However, to clarify... If we go with one test method that method calls
messageBody:
Uwe,

We have done it both ways and seen that it is 6 one way, 1/2 a dozen the
other. However, to clarify...

If we go with one test method that method calls other private methods for
the asserts. The only advantage I see to using two test methods is that at
first glance it may be clearer what you are testing, but in my opinion, it
doesn't take too much more effort to look at two supporting methods. One
disadvantage to this might be in metrics tools (like the one I posted in the
files section) getting confused about what is tested and what is not (my
tool doesn't get confused though :). So, your call...

-Jason

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Uwe Guenther [mailto:uwe@...]
> Sent: Tuesday, July 10, 2001 4:50 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit] names for overloading methods
>
>
>
> Hello,
>
> is there a rule how I should choose the names for overloading
> methods like these in my test class:
>
> protected byte[] engineDigest(){}
> protected int engineDigest(byte[] buf, int offset, int len){}
>
>
> 1. should I use one test method like:
>
> public void testEngineDigest(){}
>
>
>
> 2. Or should I use two names with diffrent extensions like these:
>
> public void testEngineDigest_byte(){}
> public void testEngineDigest_byte_array(){}
>
> --
> Regards Uwe Guenther
>
